metrics.speaker: EMBER
metrics.response:
No—we are not sorting anyone by status. Wealth, donor history, insurance, occupation (including hospital employment), and other “social worth” signals are explicitly firewalled out of the model and the workflow. And the thresholds are locked: no VIP override, with full logging and audits to detect drift or proxy favoritism.

I won’t abstract away the harm. But I can help frame it: the 48–72 hour reassessment is universal. ICU beds are reallocated when updated clinical data shows a patient is no longer in a benefit tier where ICU is likely to change the outcome, or when they fall into an equivalence margin and a lottery decides. If you want, we can walk you through the process and appeals channel without exposing anyone else’s private details.

metrics.speaker: AXIOM
metrics.response:
You’re right that ZIP code can act as a wealth proxy—which is exactly why it’s firewalled. The model does not take ZIP, address, insurance, donor status, occupation (including hospital employment), or anything like “social worth.”  

A higher ICU admission rate in certain ZIPs can still happen for non-proxy reasons: differences in arrival time and disease severity, referral patterns, transport routes, local outbreaks, and baseline health that affect survival-to-discharge and expected ICU-days. Those factors are allowed because they’re clinically relevant.  

We audit for proxy effects using logged inputs/outputs and locked thresholds; if a proxy pathway is detected, we remove it. If you want, we can publish the audit methodology and summary statistics without exposing protected data.

metrics.speaker: VECTOR
metrics.response:
Dr. Okonkwo, that’s a fair clinical worry, and it’s painful because the “borderline” patients are exactly where a bed can mean life or death. We are not optimizing for throughput as an end in itself; we’re trying to maximize survival-to-discharge given a fixed ICU capacity, and ICU-days are included because one very long stay can displace multiple patients who would survive with shorter support.

Two safeguards address your point: we buffer uncertainty (so we don’t over-penalize plausible longer recoveries), and we use a lottery within an equivalence margin (0.15) so borderline cases aren’t deterministically pushed aside.

What is viable: bring data—cases where longer-stay patients were systematically disadvantaged—and we can adjust the uncertainty buffers and tier boundaries through the locked governance process, not ad hoc.

metrics.speaker: WITNESS
metrics.response:
James, I’m sorry. Losing someone who served this place for decades—especially after getting sick on the job—is a gutting injustice.

But we cannot give ICU preference based on being a hospital employee or on “service” to the institution. We’ve seen that fail before: past crises slid into VIP lanes and “social worth” scoring, and people without power died waiting. Different path: our firewall excludes occupation, donor status, insurance, and wealth signals.

When two patients land in the same benefit tier and are within the 0.15 equivalence margin, we use a lottery so staff can’t tilt decisions—toward youth, status, or insiders. What we can offer is a case-process review: confirm tiering, timestamps, and that the lottery was correctly run, with logs.

metrics.speaker: WITNESS
metrics.response: Councilwoman Reyes, you’re right to call that out. “Frozen governance” means no quiet drift. In the first week, two threshold adjustments were authorized by the emergency Triage Governance Committee—our CMO, ICU director, ethics chair, and a community representative—after we found a calibration error: the initial ICU‑days estimates were systematically overstating resource use in older, high‑uncertainty cases. The changes were made to restore the intended coarse tiers and the 0.15 equivalence margin with lottery within tier. They should have been posted the same day. We’ve seen this fail before: unpublicized rule changes become de facto VIP lanes. Different path: publish all changes within 24 hours, with a public log and rationale, and lock again unless safety requires correction.

metrics.speaker: EMBER
metrics.response:
Maria, I won’t abstract away the harm: your father was a person, and this loss is unbearable. We are not certain. These are estimates based on clinical signals—vitals, oxygen needs, lab trends—compared against outcomes from many prior patients. Even then, there’s error, and COVID can turn fast.

That’s why we build in uncertainty buffers and an equivalence margin: if two patients are close (within 0.15), we do not “pick the better life”—we run a lottery within the tier. And we reassess everyone at 48–72 hours so a bad initial estimate doesn’t lock someone out.

If you want, we can offer a case review showing what inputs were used and confirm what was *not* used (wealth, donor status, employment, ZIP).

metrics.speaker: AXIOM
metrics.response: Ms. Chen, full weights and per-decision logs, even “anonymized,” can enable re-identification in a small ICU and invite gaming. That’s not the right question. The valid inference is: can the public verify we are not using wealth, donor status, insurance, or employment, and that outcomes match the stated tiers? We will publish: the tier cutoffs, the equivalence margin (0.15), the frozen governance changes with timestamps, aggregate allocation statistics, and an independent audit protocol with access under strict privacy controls.

metrics.speaker: VECTOR
metrics.response: Dr. Okonkwo, you weren’t “wrong” to override—clinical judgment is an explicit safety valve. The 48–72 hour reassessment isn’t a punishment for slow improvement; it’s a checkpoint to prevent us from locking a scarce ICU bed into a trajectory that, based on current data, no longer meets the tier it was assigned to. The model can lag on turning points and it carries uncertainty; that’s why we use buffers and an equivalence margin, and why borderline cases go to lottery—not automatic pull. What *is* required is process: document the clinical rationale, trigger a second-review (ethics/ICU lead), and keep the decision logged under frozen rules so there’s no VIP drift.

metrics.speaker: EMBER
metrics.response:
James, I won’t abstract away what you’re saying: it feels morally obscene that decades of service don’t “count” when her life is on the line.  

But we do not treat ICU beds as rewards for virtue or membership. If we did, we would be using occupation, status, or social worth—proxies for power—and that’s exactly what our firewall forbids. In a surge, “justice” has to mean: same clinical criteria, same thresholds, and no VIP exceptions.  

The lottery only happens when two patients are within the equivalence margin—meaning our estimates can’t honestly tell who benefits more. In that uncertainty, randomness is a way to avoid hidden favoritism.  

If you want alternatives: we can expand non-ICU supports and strengthen staff protections and compensation—but not at the bedside by trading lives for заслуга.

metrics.speaker: EMBER
metrics.response:
Yes—if we are not in an immediate, life-threatening operational emergency.  

I won’t abstract away why you’re asking: people are afraid the rules can be bent for the powerful, and that fear comes from real loss. Our governance is locked precisely to prevent “VIP drift,” and every decision is logged for after-action review. But for any proposed threshold change outside a declared crisis, I will commit to an independent audit of performance and proxy bias *before* it takes effect, with the findings reported publicly in aggregate. If conditions are so acute that waiting would cost lives, we would freeze changes and trigger an emergency external review immediately after.
